prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**Warning of the Reglet in the Furniture**

'Twas twilight in the drawing-room, the armchairs creaked with dread,  
The wardrobes whispered warnings of the Reglet overhead.  
A creature born of splinters and the varnish left to dry,  
It skitters through the sofa-legs and makes the cushions cry.

Beware the Reglet, little one, that nests in cedar drawers,  
It gnaws the legs of ottomans and claws the wooden floors.  
Its eyes are made of doorknobs, its claws from rusted nails,  
Its breath smells faintly of mothballs and the dust of old folk tales.

So polish up your brolster and prepare your antimuff,  
The Reglet comes in silence when the night is quite enough.  
It slinks behind the escritoire, it nibbles at the veneer,  
It munches maple morningtide and chews by chandelier.

One eve young Tibbledora with a featherduster brave,  
Went seeking sounds of squeaking from the credence by the nave.  
She found the Reglet lurking near the warble-leg of pine,  
Its maw agape, its joints agroan, its shape a warped design.

With thudshe cried and thumpershove she toppled down a chest,  
A heavy oak in uppity-mode, it crushed the cursed pest.  
The Reglet shrieked a snibber-snap, then crumbled into ash—  
A ghost of glue and grievenail, a memory in a flash.

She dragged the wreckage past the drapes, the clocks all clanged in cheer,  
The footstools danced a fandango and the footlockers leered.  
But hush—within the cabinet, a creakling sound she heard—  
A clutch of Reglet egglets in the drawer behind the third.

'Twas twilight in the drawing-room, the armchairs creaked with dread,  
The wardrobes whispered warnings of the Reglet overhead.  
So oil your hinges nightly, and beware the skitter-scratch—  
For furniturren never die, they only hatch and hatch.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Blued Screw’s Return**  

’Tween tick and tock, the geargrove groans,  
Where whiffling wheels in whorlbines whirl;  
The horologe huffs hydric tones,  
And time’s own heart begins to curl.  

Beware the Blued Screw, brassbound brat!  
The threads that tease, the slots that snag!  
Shun the winder’s wiry gnat,  
And shun the spring’s rebounding brag!  

He took his microwrench in grip,  
Long lurked in loupe-light, low and still;  
Then paused where pivot-pistons slip—  
And waited, breathless, clockward chill.  

One, two! One, two! Through ruby race  
The micro-glides, the steelspate sings;  
He flicked the foul flyback apace,  
And lo! the lever leapt its springs.  

"And hast thou slain the Blued Screw’s bind?  
Come calibrate, my beamish lad!"  
"O frabjous fix! It’s re-aligned!"  
He chortled in his joyclad glad.  

’Tween tick and tock, the geargrove groans,  
Where whiffling wheels in whorlbines whirl;  
The horologe huffs hydric tones—  
Yet time, unseized, resumes unfurl.
label: high

<C6_think>Early admonition is present in the second stanza (“Beware the Blued Screw, brassbound brat!”) equivalent to the canonical caution.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation is shown in the third stanza: “He took his microwrench in grip,” “long lurked,” “paused... waited” indicating planning and armament before the encounter.</C7_think>
<C8_think>There is a clear encounter/confrontation described in the fourth stanza ("Through ruby race... He flicked the foul flyback") representing a meeting with an adversary.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive action is presented in stanza four with the act of "flicked the foul flyback apace" and lever springing, resolving the central tension.</C9_think>

<C17_think>No lines match any canonical lines verbatim; wording is different and original throughout.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens used are minimal: 'beamish' only canonical word observed; under limit of 8 distinct canonical terms.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Long lines are about 8-9 syllables (“The horologe huffs hydric tones”=8), short lines about 5-7 (“And time’s own heart begins to curl”=7). Pattern persists throughout quatrains clearly.</C19_think>
<C20_think>End rhymes at lines 2 and 4 vary with no more than 2 repeats of the same rhyme throughout; rhyme words like snag, brag, whirl, curl, still, chill, sing, spring, lad, glad, unfurl show diversity.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No overuse of any single content word outside ring echo; the poem is lexically varied without excessive repetition.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages derive from distinct roots: geargrove, whorlbines, horologe, microwrench, steelspate, flyback, joyclad, ruby race; suffix variation present; no single suffix dominates >50%.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Topic is consistent and clearly a parody/adaptation in the style of "Jabberwocky" focused on the "Blued Screw" as a creature/obstacle; adheres strictly to the style and subject.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext of time, clockwork, struggle against mechanical foe is coherent and implied throughout, giving a motif of measuring and mastering time, an undertone of control and cyclical battle.</C24_think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Brumous Stubble-Murmur  
(An After-Warning, writ in clack-clat clods)

I.  
When stubble-whiskered gloamings glurn  
and murkles hish the field,  
beware the flust’ry Gracklesnipe—  
its brindle beak unsealed.  

II.  
Sharpen, ye clodhops, splinter-scythes;  
sip thistle-brew, grow grim.  
Let pocket-crisp of crackle-seed  
rime solid in each limb.  

III.  
Through husk-hush, dusk, a whoofle-thrash—  
the murmuration dips;  
a single speckle-blot grows spine:  
the Gracklesnipe unzips!  

IV.  
With clapper-caw it corkscrews down,  
all serrates, shriek and spangle;  
but—snick!—your sickle skewers shade,  
you twist the iron angle.  

V.  
Home-trod by lantern’s glinter-glow,  
the hearth-hush hunkers tight;  
stubble’s hush; sky’s hush; heart’s hush—  
still... murmurs tatter night.  

VI.  
When stubble-whiskered gloamings glurn  
and murkles hish the field,  
mind how the hush you hacked returns—  
new flust’ry flocks unsealed.
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "Brumous Stubble-Murmur" plus a parenthetical subtitle are present before the first stanza; non-empty title present.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 6 stanzas total, each with exactly 4 lines; stanza count is between 5 and 8; all quatrains.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Lines alternate longer/shorter in most stanzas with a content-word difference of 2 or more; about 5 of 6 stanzas clearly show this pattern (≥60%).</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme of lines 2 and 4 occurs in at least 4 of 6 stanzas; rhyme is mostly slant but consistently in expected positions; no AABB dominance observed.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoes the first stanza closely with ≥2 content words repeated and a clear refrain-like repetition of the first stanza's key lines.</C5_think>
<C6_think>There is an early admonition: stanza I says "beware the flust’ry Gracklesnipe," acting as a clear warning to the protagonist.</C6_think>
<C7_think>In stanza II, protagonist prepares by sharpening tools ("sharpen, ye clodhops, splinter-scythes") and strengthening ("sip thistle-brew, grow grim"), satisfying preparation criteria.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Stanza IV depicts the encounter with the Gracklesnipe through vivid action ("clapper-caw," "snick!," "your sickle skewers shade"), a clear meeting/confrontation present.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive action is indicated in stanza IV with the sickle skewering the adversary's shadow, suggesting resolution of central tension.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return/celebration is present in stanza V with "Home-trod by lantern’s glinter-glow," "hearth-hush hunkers tight," but the mood is subdued, no jubilant acknowledgement; more reflective than celebratory; borderline but insufficiently jubilant.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Distinct invented coinages exceed 8 easily (examples: Brumous, Stubble-Murmur, glurn, murkles, flust’ry, Gracklesnipe, clodhops, whoofle-thrash, clapper-caw, snick, glinter-glow, murmuration, unzips), well over threshold.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least one coinage or clear invented term (e.g., "glurn," "clodhops," "whoofle-thrash," "clapper-caw"), so coinage is well spread.</C12_think>
<C13_think>The adversary is named "Gracklesnipe," a non-canonical creature central to action; this satisfies creature naming.</C13_think>

<C16_think>The narrative arc follows canonical order: warning (stanza I), preparation (II), encounter (III-IV), decisive act (IV), return (V), ring echo (VI); sequence intact and clear.</C16_think>

<C19_think>Long lines generally around 8–9 syllables and short lines about 5–7; pattern in stanza I: lines 1 and 3 longer, 2 and 4 shorter roughly matching Jabberwocky’s pattern; consistent across majority of stanzas (≥60%).</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme pairs (2,4) use varied endings across stanzas, no exact rhyme word repeated more than twice, excluding ring echo; varied rhyme scheme.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No single content word clearly overused; coinages predominate; lexical repetition is guarded outside ring echo.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages show multiple distinct roots with no one dominant suffix or pattern accounting for more than half of coinages; variety evident in forms and roots.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Poem clearly addresses a "Jabberwocky"-style monster narrative with warning, confrontation, slaying, and return; theme aligns well with original topic.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext of cyclical menace and consequences implied in repetition and renewed flocks unsealed; an undertone of inevitability and reflection beyond surface action.</C24_think>
